id-00001.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +4 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 11 (2d8 + 2) piercing damage.
id-00001.name: Morningstar

id-00002.desc: Melee or Ranged Weapon Attack: +4 to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 30 ft./120 ft., one target. Hit: 9 (2d6 + 2) piercing damage.
id-00002.name: Javelin

text.p: Bugbears are cruel and unruly humanoids that surviveby raiding and hunting. They live to bully the weak and dislike being bossed around. They have bestial features,with large wedge-shaped ears, ursine noses, and maws filled with sharp fangs. Despite their intimidating builds, bugbears move with surprising stealth and are fond of setting ambushes.

King Grol is a fierce old bugbear. He rules the Cragmaws through pure intimidation. Age has stooped his shoulders and hunched his back, but he remains surprisingly agile and strong. He is demanding and vindictive, and no Cragmaw dares to cross him.

id-00001.desc: A melee weapon deals one extra die of its damage when the bugbear hits with it (included in the attack).
id-00001.name: Brute

id-00002.desc: If the bugbear surprises a creature and hits it with an attack during the first round of combat, the target takes an extra 7 (2d6) damage from the attack.
id-00002.name: Surprise Attack

id-00001.desc: The bear makes two attacks: one with its bite and one with its claws.
id-00001.name: Multiattack

id-00002.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 8 (1d8 + 4) piercing damage.
id-00002.name: Bite

id-00003.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 11 (2d6 + 4) slashing damage.
id-00003.name: Claws

id-00001.desc: The bear has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on smell.
id-00001.name: Keen Smell

text.p: Set the story, Andy wrote a starting document that's separate from this one. Our heroes and Gundrenâ€™s cousin Dwarf-lady set off with their supply wagon and got ambushed. Spent the whole night on our first fight. Again, probably not a surprise to anyone. Had to figure out mechanics. Killed a three Kobolds, a big guy/leader in armor and he summoned a mud monster that we also beat. Went pretty well overall. Acilper suggested checking the belongings of fallen foes. Got some gold. Discovered Gundrenâ€™s map case and dead horses at the scene. Dorgib made some horse jerky :)
Tymenos receives a message from Sister Garaele, a cleric in the town of Phandalin a tenday journey from Hythe.
Acilper is tracking a clue about his clan's demise and meets up with Gundren who offers him passage east in exchange for guarding his caravan.
Dorgib joins the caravan to Phandalin after learning it is a growing town probably in need of a talented bard.
Brosenelyn, Gundren's cousin who runs the caravan teams, drives the wagon while Dorgib tells tales to pass the time.
After butchering the horses and finding Gundren's map case, Brosenelyn suggests the party continue Phandalin to deliver the supplies and restock food.
She requests the party's assistance to find Gundren.

Went on into town, Gundren is pretty tough and we figured we had time. Got paid for the supplies. Acilper bought ball-bearings. Gundrenâ€™s brothers are expected back soon, but we didnâ€™t wait. Went back to the scene of the crime and found a cave. Dorgib took the lead, triggered tons of traps but amazingly DCed out of them without getting hurt or sounding the alarm. Ambushed the supposed look-out Kobolds with our skillz then went in. Encountered some wolves, but they were tied up so we retreated. Fought four Kobolds in a room with K-made cisterns, Tim contributed almost nothing to this fight due to fumbles. Kobolds are known for their traps. Left one tunnel/room/whatever unexplored, had to turn at a tee.

The party followed Bronselyn's advice and continued on to Phandalin to deliver the supplies and restock. Dorgib and Acilper stayed with the wagon while Bronselyn and Tymenos met with Elmar Barthen of Barthen's Provisions. They spoke with Elmar of Gundren's kidnapping. Upset by the news, he offered whatever provisions the party needed and promised to let Gundren's brothers know when they returned from their camping trip in a couple of days.
Restocked, the party immediately headed back out, returning to the site of the ambush, taking turns resting in the wagon so they would not be fatigued when they arrived.

From there they picked up the trail of several kobolds, two larger sets of prints, and the signs of two bodies being dragged. The trail led past a snare trap and a pit trap. Dorgib, in the lead, managed to detect neither trap but evaded them both.

In the darkest hours of the night, the party arrived at the mouth of a cave guarded by two inattentive kobolds. They surprised and tore down the kobolds quickly, seemingly without alerting anything inside the cave.

Proceeding into the cave, they quickly came upon three wolves, hungry and angry, chained to an iron rod in the floor. The three each attempted animal handling to calm the wolves, aided by the Dorgib's horse jerky. Tymenos succeeded in calming a wolf while Dorgib and Acilper failed miserably.

Unsure what to do about the wolves, the party discussed for a while whether to kill the wolves or go on, afraid that the wolves would get free and attack them from behind as they explored this cave. Ultimately they decided to go on, not killing the wolves.

Once a side passage presented itself the party took it to the west, climbing the rocky incline toward another fork in the road. This time they chose to go right, and ended up at a bridge overlooking the previous path and stream.

They spotted a kobold on the bridge at the same time it noticed them, and chased it across the bridge and down another tunnel to the twin pools cave where three more kobolds waited. Acilper took down the fleeing kobold with a bowshot to the back. Tymenos badly missed an eldritch blast and nearly broke the levy holding one of the pools. Bronselyn took down another with her crossbow. Dorgib finished off last two kobolds with a rapier through the chest and a dagger in the throat.
The party now stands in the wave pool room, deciding if they should explore the rest of the cave or head up the flight of stairs before them to a room where a campfire burns cheerfully.

Boss fight against an evil Monk. Was a tough go. 8 Kobolds, Monk who had a wand that took dwarf-lady out of the fight and a bear who was the monkâ€™s pet that came out of nowhere after once we thought it was over. Dorgib ended up getting knocked unconscious, but not before taking out half the baddies with AoE thunderwave at start of fight. The ball-bearings were surprisingly effective :). We got gold, healing potions, the wand, and a statue? Dolgib kind of became the group treasurer. Acilper took the statue. Tim took the healing potions. Was a long fight due to number of foes, took most of the night. Bronselyn, her name is Bronselyn.

Awating the party in Klarg's Cave is a monk named Hemrath, sitting crosslegged before the fire, back to the stairway. On each side of the doorway are two kobolds standing guard inattentively as only kobolds can. Two other kobolds are gathering trash and throwing it down the crevice in the back of the room.

His black bear companion, Mecho, is laying in her nest in a dark corner, gnawing on a bone: probably a kobold. She is injured from a previous fight with the wolves and does not join the battle unless called.

Hemrath detects as they approach any characters with a Dexterity (Stealth) ability check less than 14. He rises from his meditation and faces the party, where they can see his face is bright red, as if sunburned. He says aloud, but seemingly to himself "We of the stone must be stronger than the fire". More softly, he continues, "A difficult task." To the party he asks, "What business do you have with the Black Stone?"
If asked about the Black Stone, he replies, "A group of like-minded individuals. You will be hearing more from us soon enough."

If the characters attempt to leave, he motions toward the kobolds standing guard at either side of the door. "I don't think I can allow you to leave. The Black Stone is not quite ready to make their presence here public knowledge." He pulls his Wand of Earthen Grasp, points it and Bronselyn and speaks a word of arcane power. A large hand of stone emerges from the ground behind her and grasps her tightly, pinning her arms to her body and preventing her from moving or attacking.
The kobolds unsheath their daggers and start advancing on the party.
When Hemrath's HP drops to half or the party destroys all of the kobolds, he turns his head to the corner of the room, crying "Come to me, Mecho! These intruders have been killing your dinner!"

Went back to the room that was unexplored. Tried to talk to six Kobolds but ended up fighting them anyway. Beat them and got enough experience to level up! Saved a human named Sildar. Learned a lot from him, found a stash of goods that we took back to a merchant in town (Lynene at Lionâ€™s Shield, she knows Bronselyn) for a reward. Sildar is in Lordâ€™s Alliance with Gundren. Mentions Iarno Albrik, a wizard who is also in their group, been missing for 2 months.

Went to the common room. Dorgib entertained the crowd and Tim chatted up the locals, learned a lot of information on 13, 21, and 16 CHR rolls. Orc raiders seen in region to East on the Triboar trail. Thell Dendrar a local woodcarver fought with the Red Brands and got himself murdered right in the face., took body. Red Brands are a gang in town, all dressed in same red armor, hassling everyone except the owner of the Minerâ€™s Exchange, sheâ€™s tough. RBs staying at the Sleeping Giant. Karp Alderleaf, a local boy, saw RBs coming out of a tunnel near his farm, also on east side of town with the Sleeping Giant.

Spent the whole two hours creating our characters. I donâ€™t think this was a surprise to anyone. Acilper the Dwarvish fighter, Dorgib the Sylva cactus bard w/ accordian, and Tymenos (Tim) the (Enchanter) Tiefling warlock. Looked at homebrew backgrounds on 5e wiki. Chose great ones for each of our characters. Tried to finalize equipment, spells, proficiencies, etc.

Orcs! Magic ranged attack 12 missed against AC,14 hit, they also had +5 hit, one Orc -15 died. Two more Orcs attack from west, started 10â€™ away. 14 didnâ€™t kill. Confirmed that they had 15HP. Tim got knocked unconscious, after the fight Dorgib cured. Fallen orc weapons might be worth 2GP, stashed them behind a tree for later. Band on arm, from Wyvern Tor group! 120XP. Took a short rest w/ song, then long rest. Conyberry - stopped in, Tim got +22 history, used to be a trading post on triboar trail. Midpoint between Triboar and Neverwinter, 10 years ago sacked by Barbarians from the North. Headed NW to Agatha the Banshee, entered her hut, gave comb, received one answer. RNG been afflicted with powerful magic. In order to heal him, must destroy or disrupt the source of that magic. Gives us a bonus clue, source of magic lies further west in NW woods, underground. Offer further services, she vanishes. Backed away, now must try to figure out what to do next. Got 14GP, 14SP, 18CP from Orcs.

Spent the whole session interrogating locals. Started with Sister Garaele - Red Brands are a menace, leader is Glass Staff, no one has seen him, no one knows where HQ is. Hurt RNG is Wilkin, as local as a RNG can be, lives north of town. Rolled 22 medicine check. No fever, in a coma. Slightly responsive, not contagious, not sweating. Awakened Mind gives images of dark forrest, small pool with something dark in it, monsters and creatures that he believes he is fighting. He stumbled into town and was found by Emalone, waitress and cook at Stonehill, no obvious serious wounds. Sister wants us to go see a Banshee in the NW woods, Agatha, she tried to go but was ambushed by orcs. Gave us a silver bedazzled comb as offering. Orcs were near Coneybery, a day N&E. Sheâ€™s heard of Iarno, but doesnâ€™t know Black Stone.
Went to get Dorgib some armor and darts, haggled well and got more for his old armor than expected.

Minerâ€™s exchange, run by Haliya, half orc lady, has 5 tough looking helpers. Not a fan of RBs, but doesnâ€™t have the muscle to get rid of them, insight check, can trust her, but something funny about her saying she doesnâ€™t have the manpower. RB HQ is under the manor, tunnel probably. Offers 100g bounty for getting rid of Glass Staff. Much debate in party over what that means exactly.

Talked to Emalone, was surprised by RNG, because he can take care of himself. Story matches Garaeleâ€™s. Wilkin kept repeating stuff like â€œdonâ€™t trust the waterâ€¦â€ He seemed to be yelling and fighting something that only he could see in his head.

Went to town hall, notice board with large sign offering reward to slay orcs. Town hall has bell tower and cellar, better built than most in town. Townmaster elected 6 months ago. Not much going on behind his eyes, but jovial, Harbin Wester. Orcs linked to Wyvern Tor, south of Old Owl Well. Checked with Bronselyn, sheâ€™s going looking for Gundrenâ€™s brothers, not coming with us. We set out to kill the orcs, and get attacked!!!
This fey creatue became so evil and demented that she was banished from the Feywild to the Prime Material Plane and imprisoned in her barrow lair.
As a result of the eruption of Mount Hotenow in 1451 DR, the prison weakened and allowed Annis to begin spreading her influence through Neverwinter Wood.
Annis wants to free herself, to return to the Feywild and enact retribution on those who imprisoned her. If the players free her instead of killing her, Annis will immediately Plane Shift away

Annis uses her powers of illusion and confusion to lure creatures to her lair where she encourages them to drink from a sparkling fountain. This fountain is an illusion and drinking from it allows Annis to feed upon them, gaining strength.
Wilkin, a ranger residing near Phandalin, managed to escape before being completely consumed, though is currently in a feverish coma.
Annis is not at full strength due to the wards imprisoning her, but she has control of her lair and can use it against interlopers.

Annis's lair is a dank and foul-smelling barrow beneath her corrupted spring-fed pool. Her illusion magic , however, makes the lair seem something like a roman bath, with marble floors and a crystal clear fountain pool in the center. The tunnel exit to the rest of the lair is obscured behind a frieze.
Once in the barrow proper, the illusion fades and the lair becomes a confusing maze of dark tunnels filled with refuse, slime, mold, and decaying dead animals.
On initiative count 20, the Annis can use her lair to take certain actions. Every action must be used before one can be used again.
Since the Red Brands are mostly human, the adventurers may have trouble impersonating them to intercept a resupply shipment.
Who is controlling the shipments?
What kind of encounter is this? How many merchants, guards?
Travelling at night, 2 merchents, 6 guards. 3 red brands

description.p: This +1 battleaxe is inscribed with the name "Talon," in gleaming silver and its double heads are inscribed with a bird of prey with outspread wings. It once belonged to a great knight named Aldith Tresendar, known as the Black Hawk. A character who succeeds on a DC 15 Intelligence (History) check recognizes the sword and recalls this lore.
Sir Aldith died fighting off the orcs that attacked through the hidden caverns below his manor. Talon was lost here until the nothic found it.
You have a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.
Magic weapons are unmistakably finer in quality than their ordinary counterparts. You have a +1 bonus to the attack rolls and damage rolls you make with this weapon.
A stone wand about 8 inches long with a small brown hand carved at one end, open as if to grasp something.
This wand has 1 charge. While holding it, you can use an action to expend its charge to cast Maximilian's Earthen Grasp from it. The spell save DC for the wand is 12.
The wand regains its expended charge daily at dawn.

id-00002.name: Wand of Earthen Grasp
id-00002.nonidentified: The spiral pattern along the length of this wand ends in a stylised bolt of force.

text.p: Tymenos, I hope this letter finds you and your people in good health. How fortunate for Hythe that someone of your skill and caring chose to settle nearby!

Flattery aside, I am writing to request your help with a situation that recently occurred in Phandalin. A local man, a ranger, came down with symptoms that remind me of the disease that afflicted Hythe those few years ago.

Unfortunately the remedy you came up with for that disease isn't working for this one and something about the illness is resisting my clerical abilities. With daily healing I'm able to keep him from getting worse but I'm not making any headway on curing him.
If you're not too busy, I could really use your help with this situation. I'm out of my depth and could use the assistance of a man of your talents.

The easiest way to find Phandalin is to seek out a dwarf named Gundren Rockseeker at Seeking Rocks Equipment Co. in Neverwinter. He makes regular deliveries of provisions here and is always happy to bring along extra muscle.
With Respect,
Garaele -- Sister of Tymora
Phandalin

Mono is the name of the clawed cyclops. Go down passage that leads to RB, two doors. Left door is “food.” Send Mono in, they’re used to him, he only eats dead food. Dorgib goes in with a cloak on and says he’s new recruit, was sent by glass staff. Asking questions, how many are there, mention bugbears and a goblin. 4 of them. RBs don’t know why Glass Staff brought them in.

Series of persuasion, sleight of hand, sleep spell, put two to sleep, 2 drunk. Start stabbing in the back. Kill one with a crit short sword, offhand short sword, and hand axe during surprise round. Second one falls before he can act. Open door in this room, passage, stairs up to cavernous room. Or another door further down passage. DM asks if anyone speaks Goblin.

Gonna kick in door, scatter ball bearings and back into corridor. Bad smell. 3 Bugbears and one Goblin. Dorgib does 5 dart damage to a Bugbear when it comes into passage.15 more damage from D. Whispers. 20 total made him heavy. 8 damage was still “wounded.” 19 more for 27 total kills it. 5 also takes one to wounded. 26 is heavy. They have 27 hit points.
1 hp left, tries to surrender, nature check we know that Bugbears are chaotic evil, murder him. Needed 1 damage, did 16. Got a key from one of the bugbears.

Intimidate the Goblin, he speaks common. Glass Staff has room on north side. Came with the bugbears, sent by Black Spider to help Glass Staff. Black Spider is a dark skinned elf. Came from Wave Echo Cave. Bronselyn says Gundren is looking for WEC. Goblin thinks they came from east. Acilper good Nature check, considered evil, this one seems to be telling the truth, no threat. Going to tell him to get out, but going to lock him in until we deal with GS. Tells us there are cells by coffin room, they keep prisoners to sell as slaves. As far as he knows supplies are food and weapons and cloaks. Lock Droop in and leave.
Worried about Mono turning on us, give him the Bugbears, tell him to chill.

Look at map. Decided to go confront GS, send Bron to cover secret exit. Dorgib walks in to GS room. Workshop, no people, rat. Another door. Walk into sleeping room, covered in scarlet drapes, wooden chest. No one in there. Secret door out, we hear Bron shout “Halt!” Time to fight Glass Staff!

Shortish man, dark beard, brown robes w/ red trim. In his hand is a glass staff. We talk too long, his staff glows and he is covered with a shimmering aura. Looks to Bronselyn, but doesn’t seem to work. Attack!!!

15 is a hit. 16 damage took him to heavy. Bronselyn kills him with a crossbow bolt. Go back to chest, not locked or trapped. 180 silver, 130 gold, 5 carnelians, 2 peridots, 1 pearl. Bottles of mercury, dragon bile, and powdered nightshade, worth about 25 gold each. Was trying to brew potions of invisibility, but no successes. Alchemy text books, histories of the region, dwarvish book about region describes lost mine, but we think it might be wave echo cave, can hear crashing waves in the cave, duh! Forge of Spells is mentioned in the book as being inside mine, author was Ermon, had a magic mace named Lightbringer that was supposed to be made there. Can see on his writing desk is a letter, from Black Spider to Iarno Albrek, warning of a group of strangers who are probably us.
Staff is Staff of Defense, also had Scroll of Fireball, and scroll of Charm Person.
Next time, prisoners, Goblin, interrogate 2 sleepy guys and 3 guys up top.

Spent the whole two hours creating our characters. I don’t think this was a surprise to anyone. Acilper the Dwarvish fighter, Dorgib the Sylva cactus bard w/ accordian, and Tymenos (Tim) the (Enchanter) Tiefling warlock. Looked at homebrew backgrounds on 5e wiki. Chose great ones for each of our characters. Tried to finalize equipment, spells, proficiencies, etc.

Spent the whole night on our first fight. Again, probably not a surprise to anyone. Had to figure out mechanics. Killed a three Kobolds, a big guy/leader in armor and he summoned a mud monster that we also beat. Went pretty well overall. Acilper suggested checking the belongings of fallen foes. Got some gold. Discovered Gundren’s map case and dead horses at the scene. Dorgib made some horse jerky :)

Left one tunnel/room/whatever unexplored, had to turn at a tee.

Was a tough go. 8 Kobolds, Monk who had a wand that took dwarf-lady out of the fight and a bear who was the monk’s pet that came out of nowhere after once we thought it was over. Dorgib ended up getting knocked unconscious, but not before taking out half the baddies with AoE thunderwave at start of fight. The ball-bearings were surprisingly effective :). We got gold, healing potions, the wand, and a statue? Dolgib kind of became the group treasurer. Acilper took the statue. Tim took the healing potions. Was a long fight due to number of foes, took most of the night. Bronselyn, her name is Bronselyn.

Went back to the room that was unexplored. Tried to talk to six Kobolds but ended up fighting them anyway. Beat them and got enough experience to level up! Saved a human named Sildar. Learned a lot from him, found a stash of goods that we took back to a merchant in town (Lynene at Lion’s Shield, she knows Bronselyn) for a reward. Sildar is in Lord’s Alliance with Gundren. Mentions Iarno Albrik, a wizard who is also in their group, been missing for 2 months.

Went to the common room. Dorgib entertained the crowd and Tim chatted up the locals, learned a lot of information on 13, 21, and 16 CHR rolls. Orc raiders seen in region to East on the Triboar trail. Thell Dendrar a local woodcarver fought with the Red Brands and got himself murdered right in the face., took body. Red Brands are a gang in town, all dressed in same red armor, hassling everyone except the owner of the Miner’s Exchange, she’s tough. RBs staying at the Sleeping Giant. Karp Alderleaf, a local boy, saw RBs coming out of a tunnel near his farm, also on east side of town with the Sleeping Giant.

Spent the whole session interrogating locals. Started with Sister Garaele - Red Brands are a menace, leader is Glass Staff, no one has seen him, no one knows where HQ is. Hurt RNG is Wilkin, as local as a RNG can be, lives north of town. Rolled 22 medicine check. No fever, in a coma. Slightly responsive, not contagious, not sweating. Awakened Mind gives images of dark forrest, small pool with something dark in it, monsters and creatures that he believes he is fighting. He stumbled into town and was found by Emalone, waitress and cook at Stonehill, no obvious serious wounds. Sister wants us to go see a Banshee in the NW woods, Agatha, she tried to go but was ambushed by orcs. Gave us a silver bedazzled comb as offering. Orcs were near Coneybery, a day N&E. She’s heard of Iarno, but doesn’t know Black Stone.
Went to get Dorgib some armor and darts, haggled well and got more for his old armor than expected.

Miner’s exchange, run by Haliya, half orc lady, has 5 tough looking helpers. Not a fan of RBs, but doesn’t have the muscle to get rid of them, insight check, can trust her, but something funny about her saying she doesn’t have the manpower. RB HQ is under the manor, tunnel probably. Offers 100g bounty for getting rid of Glass Staff. Much debate in party over what that means exactly.

Talked to Emalone, was surprised by RNG, because he can take care of himself. Story matches Garaele’s. Wilkin kept repeating stuff like “don’t trust the water…” He seemed to be yelling and fighting something that only he could see in his head.

Went to town hall, notice board with large sign offering reward to slay orcs. Town hall has bell tower and cellar, better built than most in town. Townmaster elected 6 months ago. Not much going on behind his eyes, but jovial, Harbin Wester. Orcs linked to Wyvern Tor, south of Old Owl Well. Checked with Bronselyn, she’s going looking for Gundren’s brothers, not coming with us. We set out to kill the orcs, and get attacked!!!

Orcs! Magic ranged attack 12 missed against AC,14 hit, they also had +5 hit, one Orc -15 died. Two more Orcs attack from west, started 10’ away. 14 didn’t kill. Confirmed that they had 15HP. Tim got knocked unconscious, after the fight Dorgib cured. Fallen orc weapons might be worth 2GP, stashed them behind a tree for later. Band on arm, from Wyvern Tor group! 120XP - later corrected to 135. Took a short rest w/ song, then long rest. Conyberry - stopped in, Tim got +22 history, used to be a trading post on triboar trail. Midpoint between Triboar and Neverwinter, 10 years ago sacked by Barbarians from the North. Headed NW to Agatha the Banshee, entered her hut, gave comb, received one answer. RNG been afflicted with powerful magic. In order to heal him, must destroy or disrupt the source of that magic. Gives us a bonus clue, source of magic lies further west in NW woods, underground. Offer further services, she vanishes. Backed away, now must try to figure out what to do next. Got 14GP, 14SP, 18CP from Orcs.

Heading back towards Wyvern Tor and Orcs, no stopping in Conyberry. Good Stealth check. Find an old broken tower. No one in courtyard, tent set up. Tower inside an old wall. Perception check, Tim smells death. This is not WT. Set the tent on fire, got a bald guy in red robes running out. Tattoo on his head, good Arcana check - necromantic symbol, studies in the school of necromancy. Zombies stumbling out of broken tower. 4 or 5, with more coming out. Robe signify a Wizard of Thay, land far to the east. Wizards from there are power hungry, not usually good. Try to talk our way out of it. Offers to give us potion of healing and scroll of Darkness. Also, after mentioning that there could be new zombies soon had a good persuasion check and got two zombie helpers. Sprinkle us with magic zombie dust.

Heading towards Orcs. Setting up ambush with Zombies, found 4 of them. INT check on Zombies, if they get knocked down, sometimes they get back up. Surprised them! Free turn. Whipped ‘em pretty good! Alex took a 17-point critical, one zombie took some damage too.

Setting second ambush, trying again. Bad stealth check. Two Orcs. Got ambushed in turn by 3rd Orc and half-ogre, Jarod and I both took 8 damage surprise. Tim got knocked out first turn before getting to take any action. Half-Ogre took between 28 and 33 to kill. 14 was a hit on attack throw to orc. Barely won this fight, bad luck, but zombies tanked and did damage, they saved us. Alex got knocked out.

Woke up after long rest, area clear due to orcs in the area. Level 3!!! Sending zombies in front of us towards wyvern tor, trying to draw orcs out. Wyvern Tor is a long abandoned home of a large nest of wyverns, they left decades ago. Tall hill w/ perches, probably caves used by orcs. No one knows how deep, but some sort of shelter on hill. No sign of wyverns (phew!). High perception rolls, smell smoke. Bad stealth check, send zombies towards smoke. Find a single orc on guard duty. Zombies got really close. 20 perception check, nothing behind us. Tim hears armor/weapon movement and voices from cave.
Try to set ambush at mouth of cave, giant creature comes out, followed by orc. Big guy has bone necklaces, helmet, seems to be the leader. 10’ tall. Two more orcs. Brughor Axebiter and Gog!

Fighting boss orc, ogre, and two orcs. 17 hit ogre, 12 hit orc, not wearing much. Brughor had 32 or less. Zombies rocked again! Ogre had 67 or less. Critical hit w/ Ray of Frost, mighty blow, 3d8 instead of 1d8, sniped him off. Orcs of the Many Arrows tribe. Claim orc patch and scalp of leader and ogre as proof of win. Sent single (one armed) zombie survivor back home with necklaces and orc arm. Ogre had 59HP.

In cave unlocked chest - inside is plunder from bad deeds, 750cp, 180sp, 62electrum, 30gp, 3 vials of perfume. Gonna take a half-long-rest for Dorgib, ask about. 750xp, 250 each. Need to head back to town. Need to ask mayor about perfume.

Started by checking the rest of the hill, exploring a new cave we found. Smell natural beast. Keep going deeper, reached a tee. Spiders, bad nature check, not much idea about them. Also hear bats. Decide to go after them. Two giant wolf spiders. 10 misses. 5 damage to Tim from that spider, Hellish Rebuke, save, 10 damage made heavy damage. 6 damage from Dorgib made other spider heavy as well. Two swarms of bats attack from behind! 2 more damage kill the Ceiling spider, so 11 or 12 HP. Alex hits bats for 10 only brought them to wounded. 15 is a hit. Hex plus successful EB does 15 damage, brought to heavy. 12 is a hit. 8 more damage killed it, so less than 33. Won with no deaths! 200XP!

Found a short sword for Dorgib on our way back. See birds, hot outside. Make it back to town, see fat stupid mayor. Slaps scalps on the table, Sildar there too. Got 100GP plus a bonus 50GP for our hard work, extra work, and persuasion checks. 1250XP to split for completing the quest! Ask about the perfume, no one is sure why the orcs had perfume. Orcs took more than that from the Caravans, so not sure why perfume was the only thing. Sildar knows Many Arrows tribe of Orcs, almost an unfriendly nation led by particularly intelligent Orc, bent on expansion, somewhat uneasy truce with other orcs, has gathered many smaller groups together.

Mayor still in denial over Red Brands, doesn’t want to speak out. Sildar will catch up with us later at the inn. Neverwinter Woods is full of strange things, they don’t know anything specific about RNG clues. No word on Gundren’s brothers, Bronselyn went out looking and didn’t find anything after 5 days.

Also go see the Sister, sit down and tell her everything. She’s interested in the necromancer but glad that he’s keeping to himself. Will inform townmaster. Also no clue about the perfume. Glad we got something useful out of the banshee, but answer is vague. Asks if we’ve had any mental or magical tugs in any directions. Acilper doesn’t care for trees, but has a sensation of where the forest is, Dorgib feels nothing. But as we travelled west Acilper can point towards particular direction. Tim feels something similar, identifies it as residue of Divination magic. When Agatha looked for the answer that’s what she used, her residue is imprinted on me, vague compass direction towards cursed pool. Pretty sure we could triangulate a point in the NWW. There are other RNGs who wander into Phandalin occasionally. If we asked around we could find someone. Provisioner or people at the inn. Red Brands continue to harass.

Visited armory, she doesn’t sell to Red Brands anymore, they’re decently equipped - studded leather armor, short swords. Upgrading armor. Splint for Alex, chain shirt for Jarod, studded leather for me. Bronselyn didn’t tell us much, she’ll help with Red Brands. She’s been looking for her cousins, can’t find anything. Innkeep says they’re receiving stuff in the middle of the night. They’re being supplied by someone somewhere. They beat up local seamstress pretty bad. Innkeep says he has seen 12 Red Brands. We are going to stake out near cave, see what happens. Half Orc lady visit, checking to see if she’s still willing to help.

Check in with Sildar, more of the same. Approves of the plan, but wonders about Red Brands in the Inn. Might set Sildar as watch near Sleeping Giant. Change of plan. Going to confront any RBs in the Sleeping Giant, have orc-lady and her guys watch outside of the inn to keep them from running for help.

Go into inn and start making a bunch of noise. Innkeep overcharging for bad drinks. 4 RBs stand up. We’re insulting them like crazy. Dorgib starts playing the accordion. 15 Performance check. Mention midnight shipments. FINALLY start a fight.

16 is a hit. 8 damage turned him “heavy”. 11 is a miss. 14 is hit. They have 16HP. Hellish rebuke fool who touched me to death. Easy win, but we did get some lucky rolls. Intimidate the barkeep, he’s not really a fan, but he’s a lowlife. Bad persuasion roll, but he pulls out some clean glasses. His name is Janek or “Scrumpy.” Says there are 10-15. He’s heard them argue once in a while, usually has something to do with part of the group disliking “dirty beasts” in the hideout with them.

Sildar will take care of the bodies. Guy who ran out is cool, orc lady let him go. Short rest, hit die, song of rest. 20 silver, 60 copper. I rolled hit dies back to full health, down 1 hit die. Alex same. Next week take posse up the hill.

Going to split up the bouncers with half-orc lady and Sildar. Send her to cave entrance and keep Sildar watching Manor path. Barkeep says unlikely that any of the RBs are out anywhere. Make it up to ruins without incident. Find stairs, down, landing, stone stairs down to cellar. Two doors out of cellar. West door is a bunk room. 3 RBs, two were asleep and third one Jarod put to sleep. Tie them up, gag them, and send them up above to be dealt with later. North door not locked, didn’t hear anything through it.

Trap door, Dorgib makes it across, Tim falls down 20’ pit and takes 10 damage. Acilper slips but Dorgib catches him with rope. Bronselyn jumps, misses, but Acilper grabs her. Tim rolling amazingly bad tonight, Acilper not much better.

Bust into crypt, three coffins, three skeletons, false columns in shape of trees, doors had copper plating. Need a password, maybe should have interrogated RBs we tied up. Tim prods skeletons with mage hand, We move further into the rooms and the skeletons start to move too. Or maybe not. Retracted.

Acilper swings at skeleton, 9 takes it to heavy. Another 9 smashes it to bits. Walks towards NW door, other two skeles come to life. Alex did 21 damage (crit 20) to next skele. 8 is a miss. 11 is a miss. 7 force damage takes it to heavy. 5 more damage. 15 is a hit. 10 more damage kills it.

Listen at doors. Hear something behind NE door. NW door is narrow corridor, with door pointing east at the end of a hallway. Dark. Door leading east is locked. Across from door is hidden door, heading west. Picked the lock. Lining the walls, racks of weapons. Spears,swords, crossbows, crossbow bolts. Dozen dirty red cloaks. Take a few minutes to toss the weapons into the pit. Go through secret door. Room w/ barrels, animal pelts, south side has opening to cavern, natural cavern. Scent of decaying flesh. Bridges, crevasse, etc.

Another secret door leads back to cellar. 3 doors on other side of cavern. Must cross bridge. Investigate south bridge. Didn’t investigate enough, Dorgib fell through but caught himself, other bridge supported our weight. I’ve lost track of all the doors. Creature we’ve never seen steps out at us. Yay! Clawed cyclops. Speaks telepathically. Cackles. Likes horse jerky. “Tells” us which direction the RBs are, and also several furry fleshes in other direction. Stopping here!

Lord Albrek, My spies in Neverwinter tell me that strangers are due to arrive in Phandalin. They could be working for the dwarves. Capture them if you can, kill them if you must, but don't allow them to upset our plans. See that any dwarven maps in their possession are delivered to me with haste. I'm counting on you, Iarno. Don't disappoint me.
(Signed with the Black Spider's symbol)
And we're back!!!!!

Go check out the prison, 3 partitions. Prisoners two women in South, boy in North. 2 RBs, easy kill one, second one drops his sword. Put him in the jail. Release the captives. Woman and her two children. Surviving wife of man who was murdered by RBs. Were going to sell them to slavery. Glass Staff once muttered something about the nasty business with the goblins and bugbears. Doesnâ€™t know anything about Black Spider.

Send them up top with Bron. Go check out chasm. Droop told us where some castle is, doesn't want to go home. Dorgib shoos him. Droop knows about something north of castle in forest, doesn't go there. Send him out. Go check out chasm. 20 feet down. Dorgib goes to bottom. Unnaturally cold down there. Corpses, mono lives down here. Closes to the north. To south end, cubby hole. In it there is a chest. Potions, red, viscous. Scroll of augury. Fortune telling stuff. Jewels. Battle Axe, etched w/ silver. Blades have wings etched. "Talon" is on haft. Alex can tell it's still very sharp, well made. Might be enchanted. Tim recognizes the name, famous for the region, guy who owned the manor. Famous-ish weapon.

Bring all RBs to cells, Halia and Sildar can come down. Interrogate. Sildar shocked by news of Iarno, used to be friends. Confirms GS = Iarno. RBs didn't know GS's name. Very intimidated by what Dorgib dreamt up. Glass Staff sent ravens around. Hired muscle. Who working with to smuggle stolen goods? Less-than-reputable traders that would pass through. Where are waypoints? Set up sting operation. Yes, meeting scheduled for next night. Plan!

Acilper has figured out that the axe doesnâ€™t have any special abilities, but extra sharp. +1 weapon! To both attack and damage, counts as magic weapon. Nice! Nothing else magical. Nearly to level 4!

id-00003.desc: Bronselyn makes two war pick attacks.
id-00003.name: Multiattack

id-00004.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 7 (1d8+3) piercing damage.
id-00004.name: War Pick

id-00005.desc: Ranged Weapon Attack: +3 to hit, range 100/400 ft., one target. Hit: 6 (1d10 + 1) piercing damage
id-00005.name: Heavy Crossbow

text.p: Cousin of Gundren Rockseeker, Brosenelyn manages the caravan teams running supplies between Neverwinter and Phandalin.
The party rides with her on their initial journey to Phandalin, when they find the remains of Gundren and SIldar's horses and Gundren's empty map case.

id-00001.desc: The monk makes two melee attacks.
id-00001.name: Multiattack

id-00002.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +4 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 5 (1d6 + 2) bludgeoning damage.
id-00002.name: Unarmed Strike

id-00001.desc: The monk adds 2 to its AC against one melee or ranged weapon attack that would hit it. To do so, the monk must see the attacker.
id-00001.name: Parry

text.p: Sacred Stone monks are followers of a martial philosophy that seeks to emulate the strength of rock and stone. They don gargoyle masks and use a finely honed sense of touch to measure their surroundings by contact with the ground. They avoid speaking, or extraneous thought for that matter. They live only to test themselves with deprivation and to punish those who doubt the strength of elemental earth.

id-00001.desc: While the monk is wearing no armor and wielding no shield, its AC includes its Wisdom modifier.
id-00001.name: Unarmored Defense

id-00002.desc: While the monk is wearing no armor and wielding no shield, its walking speed increases by 10 feet (included in its speed).
id-00002.name: Unarmored Movement

id-00001.desc: The giant makes two greatsword attacks.
id-00001.name: Multiattack

id-00002.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +11 to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. Hit: 28 (6d6 + 7) slashing damage.
id-00002.name: Greatsword

id-00003.desc: Ranged Weapon Attack: +11 to hit, range 60/240 ft., one target. Hit: 29 (4d10 + 7) bludgeoning damage.
id-00003.name: Rock

text.p: Master crafters and organized warriors, fire giants dwell among volcanoes, lava floes, and rocky mountains. They are ruthless militaristic brutes whose mastery of metalwork is legendary.

Fire Forged. Fire giant fortresses are built around and inside volcanoes or near magma-filled caverns. The blistering heat of their homes fuels the fire giants' forges, and causes the iron of their fortress walls to glow a comforting orange. In lands far removed from volcanic heat, fire giants mine coal to burn. Traditional smithies occupy places of honor in their demesnes, and the giants' stony fortresses constantly belch plumes of sooty smoke. In more remote outposts, fire giants burn wood to keep their forge fires lit, deforesting leagues of land in all directions.

Fire giants shun cold as much as their cousins the frost giants hate heat. They can adapt to cold environments with effort, though, keeping their hearth fires burning bright and wearing heavy woolen clothing and furs to stay warm.

Martial Experts. From birth, a fire giant is taught to embrace a legacy of war. At the cradle, its parents chant songs of battle. As children, fire giants play at war, hurling igneous rocks at one another across the banks of magma rivers. In later years, formal martial training becomes an integral part of life in the giants' fortresses and underground realms of smoke and ash.
The fire giants' songs are odes of battles lost and won, while their dances are martial formations of pounding feet that resound like smiths' hammers throughout theirsmoky halls.

Just as fire giants pass down their knowledge of crafting from generation to generation, their renowned fighting prowess comes not from wild fury but from endless discipline and training. Enemies make the mistake of underestimating fire giants based on their brutish manner, learning too late that these giants live for combat and can be shrewd tacticians.

Feudal Lords. Humanoids conquered in war become serfs to the fire giants. The serfs work the farms and fields on the outskirts of fire giant halls and fortresses, raising livestock and harvesting fields whose bounty is almost entirely tithed to the fire giant kings.

Fire giant crafters work through insight and experience rather than writing or arithmetic. Though most fire giants place little worth on such frivolousness, they sometimes keep slaves at court who are versed in such skills. Serfs not destined for court or the fields (especially dwarves) are taken to the fire giants' mountainous realms to mine ore and gemstones from deep within the earth.

Fire giants low in the ordning manage the mine tunnels and the slaves that toil there, few of which survive the difficult and dangerous work for long. Though fire giants are skilled in the engineering of mine tunnels and the gathering of ore, they place less importance on the safety of their slaves than on smelting and working the bounty those slaves produce.

Skilled Artisans. Fire giants have a fearsome reputation as soldiers and conquerors, and for their ability to burn, plunder, and destroy. Yet among the giants, fire giants produce the greatest crafters and artists. They excel at smelting and smith work, as they do at the engineering of metal and stone, and the quality of their artistry shows even in their implements of destruction and their weapons of war.

Fire giants strive to build the strongest fortresses and most potent siege weapons. They experiment with alloys to create the hardest armor, then forge the swords that can pierce it. Such work requires brawn and brains in equal measure, and fire giants high in the ordning tend to be the smartest and strongest of their kind.

Ancient empires once cast long shadows over a world that quaked beneath the giants' feet. In those lost days, these towering figures were dragon slayers, dreamers, crafters, and kings, but their kind fell from glory long ago. However, even divided among secluded clans scattered throughout the world, the giants maintain the customs and traditions of old.

Old as Legend. In remote regions of the world, the last remaining plinths, monoliths, and statues ofthe great giant empires bow their heads in desolate obscurity.Where once those empires sprawled across all lands, now the giants dwell in isolated tribes and clans.

Giants are almost as old as dragons, which were still young when the giants' heavy feet first shook the foundations of the world. As they spread across new lands, giants and dragons fought bitter generational wars that nearly brought both sides low. No living giant remembers what started the conflict, but myths and tales of their race's glorious dawn are still sung in their steadings and holdfasts, vilifying the primeval wyrms.Giants and dragons continue to harbor grudges against one another, and it is seldom that they will meet or occupy the same area without a fight.

Each of the main giant races-the cloud, fire, frost, hill, stone, and storm giants-are related by common elements of history, religion, and culture. They view one another as kindred, keeping any inherent animosity over territory and ambition to a minimum.

Giants belong to a caste structure called the ordning. Based on social class and highly organized, the ordning assigns a social rank to each giant. By understanding its place in the ordning, a giant knows which other giants are inferior or superior to it, since no two giants are equal. Each of the giant races analyzes a different combination of skills or qualities to determine the ordning. Giants make excelling in these qualities the purpose of their lives.

At the highest level of the ordning, the races of the giants are also ranked according to status. Storm giants are the highest in the ordning, followed by cloud giants, fire giants, frost giants, stone giants, hill giants, and finally giant kin such as fomorians, ettins, and ogres.

Regardless of a giant's rank among its own race, the chief of a hill giant tribe is inferior to the most common of stone giants. The lowest ranked giant of any type is superior to the highest ranked giant of an inferior type. It isn't considered evil to disrespect or even betray a giant of another type, merely rude.

When the giants' ancient empires fell, Annam, father of all giants, forsook his children and the world. He swore never to look upon either again until the giants had returned to their glory and reclaimed their birthright as rulers of the world. As a result, giants pray not to Annam but to his divine children, along with a host of hero-deities and godly villains that make up the giants' pantheon.

Chief among these gods are the children of Annam, whose sons represent each type of giant: Stronmaus for storm giants, Memnor for cloud giants, Skoraeus Stonebones for stone giants, Thrym for frost giants, Surtur for fire giants, and Grolantor for hill giants. Not all giants automatically revere their kind's primary deity, however. Many good cloud giants refuse to worship the deceitful Memnor, and a storm giant dwelling in the icy mountains of the north might pay more homage to Thrym than Stronmaus. Other giants feel a stronger connection to Annam's daughters, who include Hiatea, the huntress and home warden; Iallanis, goddess of love and peace; and Diancastra, an impetuous and arrogant trickster.

Some giants abandon their own gods and fall prey to demon cults, paying homage to Baphomet or Kostchtchie. To worship them or any other non-giant deity is a great sin against the ordning, and almost certain to make a giant an outcast.

id-00001.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +7 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 13 (2d8 + 4) slashing damage.
id-00001.name: Claws (Hag Form Only)

id-00002.desc: The hag magically polymorphs into a Small or Medium female humanoid, or back into her true form. Her statistics are the same in each form. Any equipment she is wearing or carrying isn't transformed. She reverts to her true form if she dies.
id-00002.name: Change Shape

id-00003.desc: The hag magically enters the Ethereal Plane from the Material Plane, or vice versa. To do so, the hag must have a heartstone in her possession.
id-00003.name: Etherealness

id-00004.desc: While on the Ethereal Plane, the hag magically touches a sleeping humanoid on the Material Plane. A protection from evil and good spell cast on the target prevents this contact, as does a magic circle. As long as the contact persists, the target has dreadful visions. If these visions last for at least 1 hour, the target gains no benefit from its rest, and its hit point maximum is reduced by 5 (1d10). If this effect reduces the target's hit point maximum to 0, the target dies, and if the target was evil, its soul is trapped in the hag's soul bag. The reduction to the target's hit point maximum lasts until removed by the greater restoration spell or similar magic.
id-00004.name: Nightmare Haunting (1/Day)

id-00011.damageresistances: cold, fire; bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing from nonmagical attacks that aren't silvered

id-00001.desc:
Level: 1 (Ritual)
Casting Time: 1 action
Components: V, S
Duration: Concentration, up to 10 minutes
Range: Self
For the duration, you sense the presence of magic within 30 feet of you. If you sense magic in this way, you can use your action to see a faint aura around any visible creature or object in the area that bears magic, and you learn its school of magic, if any. The spell can penetrate most barriers, but it is blocked by 1 foot of stone, 1 inch of common metal, a thin sheet of lead, or 3 feet of wood or dirt.
id-00001.name: Detect Magic (At will)

id-00002.desc:
Level: 1
Casting Time: 1 action
Components: V, S
Duration: Instantaneous
Range: 120 feet
You create three glowing darts of magical force. Each dart hits a creature of your choice that you can see within range. A dart deals 1d4 + 1 force damage to its target. The darts all strike simultaneously, and you can direct them to hit one creature or several. At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the spell creates one more dart for each slot level above 1st.
id-00002.name: Magic Missile (At will)

id-00003.desc:
Level: 7
Casting Time: 1 action
Components: V, S, M (a forked, metal rod worth at least 250 gp, attuned to a particular plane of existence)
Duration: Instantaneous
Range: Touch
You and up to eight willing creatures who link hands in a circle are transported to a different plane of existence. You can specify a target destination in general terms, such as the City of Brass on the Elemental Plane of Fire or the palace of Dispater on the second level of the Nine Hells, and you appear in or near that destination. If you are trying to reach the City of Brass, for example, you might arrive in its Street of Steel, before its Gate of Ashes, or looking at the city from across the Sea of Fire, at the DM's discretion. Alternatively, if you know the sigil sequence of a teleportation circle on another plane of existence, this spell can take you to that circle. If the teleportation circle is too small to hold all the creatures you transported, they appear in the closest unoccupied spaces next to the circle. You can use this spell to banish an unwilling creature to another plane. Choose a creature within your reach and make a melee spell attack (+6 to hit) against it. On a hit, the creature must make a DC 14 Charisma saving throw. If the creature fails this save, it is transported to a random location on the plane of existence you specify. A creature so transported must find its own way back to your current plane of existence.
id-00003.name: Plane Shift (2/day)

id-00004.desc:
Level: 2
Casting Time: 1 action
Components: V, S
Duration: Concentration, up to 1 minute
Range: 60 feet
A black beam of enervating energy springs from your finger toward a creature within range. Make a ranged spell attack (+6 to hit) against the target. On a hit, the target deals only half damage with weapon attacks that use Strength until the spell ends. At the end of each of the target's turns, it can make a DC 14 Constitution saving throw against the spell. On a success, the spell ends.
id-00004.name: Ray of Enfeeblement (2/day)

id-00005.desc:
Level: 1
Casting Time: 1 action
Components: V, S, M (a pinch of fine sand, rose petals, or a cricket)
Duration: 1 minute
Range: 90 feet
This spell sends creatures into a magical slumber. Roll 5d8; the total is how many hit points of creatures this spell can affect. Creatures within 20 feet of a point you choose within range are affected in ascending order of their current hit points (ignoring unconscious creatures). Starting with the creature that has the lowest current hit points, each creature affected by this spell falls unconscious until the spell ends, the sleeper takes damage, or someone uses an action to shake or slap the sleeper awake. Subtract each creature's hit points from the total before moving on to the creature with the next lowest hit points. A creature's hit points must be equal to or less than the remaining total for that creature to be affected. Undead and creatures immune to being charmed aren't affected by this spell. At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, roll an additional 2d8 for each slot level above 1st.
id-00005.name: Sleep (2/day)

id-00011.name: Annis

text.p: Sly and subversive, night hags want to see the virtuous turn to villainy: love turned into obsession, kindness turned to hate, devotion to disregard, and generosity to selfishness. Night hags take perverse joy in corrupting mortals.
Night hags were once creatures of the Feywild, but their foulness saw them exiled to Hades long ago, where they degenerated into fiends. The night hags have long since spread across the Lower Planes.

Soulmongers. While a humanoid sleeps, a night hag can straddle the person ethereally and intrude upon its dreams. Any creature with truesight can see the hag's spectral form straddling its prey. The ethereal hag fills her victim's head with doubts and fears, in the hope of tricking it into performing evil acts in the waking world. The hag continues her nightly visitations until the victim finally expires in its sleep. If the hag has driven her victim to commit evil deeds, she traps its corrupted soul in her soul bag (see the "Night Hag Items" sidebar) for transport to Hades.
Covens. A night hag that is part of a coven (see the "Hag Covens" sidebar) has a challenge rating of 7 (2,900 XP).

A night hag carries two very rare magic items that she must craft for herself. If either object is lost, the night hag will go to great lengths to retrieve it, as creating a new tool takes time and effort.
Heartstone. This lustrous black gem allows a night hag to become ethereal while it is in her possession. The touch of a heartstone also cures any disease. Crafting a heartstone takes 30 days.

Soul Bag. When an evil humanoid dies as a result of a night hag's Nightmare Haunting, the hag catches the soul in this black sack made of stitched flesh. A soul bag can hold only one evil soul at a time, and only the night hag who crafted the bag can catch a soul with it. Crafting a soul bag takes 7 days and a humanoid sacrifice (whose flesh is used to make the bag).
Hags represent all that is evil and cruel. Though they resemble withered crones, there is nothing mortal about these monstrous creatures, whose forms reflect only the wickedness in their hearts.

Faces of Evil. Ancient beings with origins in the Feywild, hags are cankers on the mortal world. Their withered faces are framed by long, frayed hair, horrid moles and warts dot their blotchy skin, and their long, skinny fingers are tipped by claws that can slice open flesh with a touch. Their simple clothes are always tattered and filthy.

All hags possess magical powers, and some have an affinity for spellcasting. They can alter their forms or curse their foes, and their arrogance inspires them toview their magic as a challenge to the magic of the gods, whom they blaspheme at every opportunity.

When hags must work together, they form covens, in spite of their selfish natures. A coven is made up of hags of any type, all of whom are equals within the group. However, each of the hags continues to desire more personal power.

A coven consists of three hags so that any arguments between two hags can be settled by the third. If more than three hags ever come together, as might happen if two covens come into conflict, the result is usually chaos. Shared Spellcasting. While all three members of a hag coven are within 30 feet of one another, they can each cast the following spells from the wizard's spell list but must share the spell slots among themselves:\r1st level (4 slots): identify, ray of sickness \r2nd level (3 slots): hold person, locate object \r3rd level (3 slots): bestow curse, counterspell, lightning bolt \r4th level (3 slots): phantasmal killer, polymorph\r5th level (2 slots): contact other plane, scrying \r6th level (1 slot): eyebite

For casting these spells, each hag is a 12th-level spellcaster that uses Intelligence as her spellcasting ability. The spell save DC is 12 + the hag's Intelligence modifier, and the spell attack bonus is 4 + the hag's Intelligence modifier.

Hag Eye. A hag coven can craft a magic item called a hag eye, which is made from a real eye coated in varnish and often fitted to a pendant or other wearable item. The hag eye is usually entrusted to a minion for safekeeping and transport. A hag in the coven can take an action to see what the hag eye sees if the hag eye is on the same plane of existence. A hag eye has AC 10, 1 hit point, and darkvision with a radius of 60 feet. If it is destroyed, each coven member takes 3d10 psychic damage and is blinded for 24 hours.

A hag coven can have only one hag eye at a time, and creating a new one requires all three members of the coven to perform a ritual. The ritual takes 1 hour, and the hags can't perform it while blinded. During the ritual, if the hags take any action other than performing the ritual, they must start over.
Hags name themselves in darkly whimsical ways, claiming monikers such as Black Morwen, Peggy Pigknuckle, Grandmother Titchwillow, Nanna Shug,Rotten Ethel, or Auntie Wormtooth.

Monstrous Motherhood. Hags propagate by snatching and devouring human infants. After stealinga baby from its cradle or its mother's womb, the hag consumes the poor child. A week later, the hag gives birth to a daughter who looks human until her thirteenth birthday, whereupon the child transforms intothe spitting image of her hag mother.
Hags sometimes raise the daughters they spawn, creating covens. A hag might also return the child to its grieving parents, only to watch from the shadows as the child grows up to become a horror.

Dark Bargains. Arrogant to a fault, hags believe themselves to be the most cunning of creatures, and they treat all others as inferior. Even so, a hag is open to dealing with mortals as long as those mortals show the proper respect and deference. Over their long lives, hags accumulate much knowledge of local lore, dark creatures, and magic, which they are pleased to sell.

Hags enjoy watching mortals bring about their own downfall, and a bargain with a hag is always dangerous. The terms of such bargains typically involve demands to compromise principles or give up something dear-especially if the thing lost diminishes or negates theknowledge gained through the bargain.

A Foul Nature. Hags love the macabre and festoon their garb with dead things and accentuate theirappearance with bones, bits of flesh, and filth. They nurture blemishes and pick at wounds to produce weeping, suppurating flesh. Attractive creatures evoke disgust in a hag, which might "help" such creatures by disfiguring or transforming them.

This embrace of the disturbing and unpleasant extends to all aspects of a hag's life. A hag might fly in a magical giant's skull, landing it on a tree shaped to resemble an enormous headless body. Another might travel with a menagerie of monsters and slaves kept in cages, and disguised by illusions to lure unwary creatures close. Hags sharpen their teeth on millstones and spin cloth from the intestines of their victims,reacting with glee to the horror their actions invoke.

Dark Sorority. Hags maintain contact with each other and share knowledge. Through such contacts, it is likely that any given hag knows of every other hag in existence. Hags don't like each other, but they abide by an ageless code of conduct. Hags announce their presence before crossing into another hag's territory, bring gifts when entering another hag's dwelling, and break no oaths given to other hags-as long as the oath isn't given with the fingers crossed.

Some humanoids make the mistake of thinking thatthe hags' rules of conduct apply to all creatures. When confronted by such an individual, a hag might find it amusing to string the fool along for a while before teaching it a permanent lesson.

Dark Lairs. Hags dwell in dark and twisted woods, bleak moors, storm-lashed seacoasts, and gloomy swamps. In time, the landscape around a hag's lair reflects the creature's noxiousness, such that the land itself can attack and kill trespassers. Trees twisted by darkness attack passersby, while vines snake through the undergrowth to snare and drag off creatures one at a time. Foul stinking fogs turn the air to poison, and conceal pools of quicksand and sinkholes that consume unwary wanderers.

id-00001.desc: The hag's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save DC 14, +6 to hit with spell attacks). She can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:\n At will: detect magic, magic missile\n2/day each: plane shift (self only), ray of enfeeblement, sleep
id-00001.name: Innate Spellcasting

id-00002.desc: The hag has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.
id-00002.name: Magic Resistance

id-00001.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +6 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 13 (2d8 + 4) slashing damage.
id-00001.name: Claws

id-00002.desc: The hag covers herself and anything she is wearing or carrying with a magical illusion that makes her look like another creature of her general size and humanoid shape. The illusion ends if the hag takes a bonus action to end it or if she dies. The changes wrought by this effect fail to hold up to physical inspection. For example, the hag could appear to have smooth skin, but someone touching her would feel her rough flesh. Other wise, a creature must take an action to visually inspect the illusion and succeed on a DC 20 Intelligence (Investigation) check to discern that the hag is disguised.
id-00002.name: Illusory Appearance

id-00003.desc: The hag magically turns invisible until she attacks or casts a spell, or until her concentration ends (as if concentrating on a spell). While invisible, she leaves no physical evidence of her passage, so she can be tracked only by magic. Any equipment she wears or carries is invisible with her.
id-00003.name: Invisible Passage

id-00001.desc:
Level: 0
Casting Time: 1 action
Components: V, S, M (a bit of phosphorus or wychwood, or a glowworm)
Duration: Concentration, up to 1 minute
Range: 120 feet
You create up to four torch-sized lights within range, making them appear as torches, lanterns, or glowing orbs that hover in the air for the duration. You can also combine the four lights into one glowing vaguely humanoid form of Medium size. Whichever form you choose, each light sheds dim light in a 10-foot radius. As a bonus action on your turn, you can move the lights up to 60 feet to a new spot within range. A light must be within 20 feet of another light created by this spell, and a light winks out if it exceeds the spell's range.
id-00001.name: Dancing Lights (At will)

id-00002.desc:
Level: 0
Casting Time: 1 action
Components: S, M (a bit of fleece)
Duration: 1 minute
Range: 30 feet
You create a sound or an image of an object within range that lasts for the duration. The illusion also ends if you dismiss it as an action or cast this spell again. If you create a sound, its volume can range from a whisper to a scream. It can be your voice, someone else's voice, a lion's roar, a beating of drums, or any other sound you choose. The sound continues unabated throughout the duration, or you can make discrete sounds at different times before the spell ends. If you create an image of an object-such as a chair, muddy footprints, or a small chest-it must be no larger than a5-foot cube. The image can't create sound, light, smell, or any other sensory effect. Physical interaction with the image reveals it to be an illusion, because things can pass through it. If a creature uses its action to examine the sound or image, the creature can determine that it is an illusion with a successful Intelligence (Investigation) check against your spell save DC 12. If a creature discerns the illusion for what it is, the illusion becomes faint to the creature.
id-00002.name: Minor Illusion (At will)

id-00003.desc:
Level: 0
Casting Time: 1 action
Components: V
Duration: Instantaneous
Range: 60 feet
You unleash a string of insults laced with subtle enchantments at a creature you can see within range. If the target can hear you (though it need not understand you), it must succeed on a DC 12 Wisdom saving throw or take 1d4 psychic damage and have disadvantage on the next attack roll it makes before the end of its next turn. This spell's damage increases by 1d4 when you reach 5th level (2d4), 11th level (3d4), and 17th level (4d4).
id-00003.name: Vicious Mockery (At will)

text.p: The wretched and hateful green hags dwell in dying forests, lonely swamps, and misty moors, making their homes in caves. Green hags love to manipulate other creatures into doing their bidding, masking theirintentions behind layers of deception. They lure victims to them by mimicking voices calling out for help, or drive unwanted visitors away by imitating the cries of
fierce beasts.

Obsession with Tragedy. Green hags revel in the failings and tragedies of other creatures. Theyderive joy from bringing people low and seeing hope turn into despair, not just for individuals but also for whole nations.
Covens. A green hag that is part of a coven (see the "Hag Covens" sidebar) has a challenge rating of 5 (1,800 XP).
Hags represent all that is evil and cruel. Though they resemble withered crones, there is nothing mortal about these monstrous creatures, whose forms reflect only the wickedness in their hearts.

Faces of Evil. Ancient beings with origins in the Feywild, hags are cankers on the mortal world. Their withered faces are framed by long, frayed hair, horrid moles and warts dot their blotchy skin, and their long, skinny fingers are tipped by claws that can slice open flesh with a touch. Their simple clothes are always tattered and filthy.

All hags possess magical powers, and some have an affinity for spellcasting. They can alter their forms or curse their foes, and their arrogance inspires them toview their magic as a challenge to the magic of the gods, whom they blaspheme at every opportunity.

When hags must work together, they form covens, in spite of their selfish natures. A coven is made up of hags of any type, all of whom are equals within the group. However, each of the hags continues to desire more personal power.

A coven consists of three hags so that any arguments between two hags can be settled by the third. If more than three hags ever come together, as might happen if two covens come into conflict, the result is usually chaos. Shared Spellcasting. While all three members of a hag coven are within 30 feet of one another, they can each cast the following spells from the wizard's spell list but must share the spell slots among themselves:\r1st level (4 slots): identify, ray of sickness \r2nd level (3 slots): hold person, locate object \r3rd level (3 slots): bestow curse, counterspell, lightning bolt \r4th level (3 slots): phantasmal killer, polymorph \r5th level (2 slots): contact other plane, scrying \r6th level (1 slot): eyebite

For casting these spells, each hag is a 12th-level spellcaster that uses Intelligence as her spellcasting ability. The spell save DC is 12 + the hag's Intelligence modifier, and the spell attack bonus is 4 + the hag's Intelligence modifier.

Hag Eye. A hag coven can craft a magic item called a hag eye, which is made from a real eye coated in varnish and often fitted to a pendant or other wearable item. The hag eye is usually entrusted to a minion for safekeeping and transport. A hag in the coven can take an action to see what the hag eye sees if the hag eye is on the same plane of existence. A hag eye has AC 10, 1 hit point, and darkvision with a radius of 60 feet. If it is destroyed, each coven member takes 3d10 psychic damage and is blinded for 24 hours.

A hag coven can have only one hag eye at a time, and creating a new one requires all three members of the coven to perform a ritual. The ritual takes 1 hour, and the hags can't perform it while blinded. During the ritual, if the hags take any action other than performing the ritual, they must start over.
Hags name themselves in darkly whimsical ways, claiming monikers such as Black Morwen, Peggy Pigknuckle, Grandmother Titchwillow, Nanna Shug,Rotten Ethel, or Auntie Wormtooth.

Monstrous Motherhood. Hags propagate by snatching and devouring human infants. After stealinga baby from its cradle or its mother's womb, the hag consumes the poor child. A week later, the hag gives birth to a daughter who looks human until her thirteenth birthday, whereupon the child transforms intothe spitting image of her hag mother.
Hags sometimes raise the daughters they spawn, creating covens. A hag might also return the child to its grieving parents, only to watch from the shadows as the child grows up to become a horror.

Dark Bargains. Arrogant to a fault, hags believe themselves to be the most cunning of creatures, and they treat all others as inferior. Even so, a hag is open to dealing with mortals as long as those mortals show the proper respect and deference. Over their long lives, hags accumulate much knowledge of local lore, dark creatures, and magic, which they are pleased to sell.

Hags enjoy watching mortals bring about their own downfall, and a bargain with a hag is always dangerous. The terms of such bargains typically involve demands to compromise principles or give up something dear-especially if the thing lost diminishes or negates theknowledge gained through the bargain.

A Foul Nature. Hags love the macabre and festoon their garb with dead things and accentuate theirappearance with bones, bits of flesh, and filth. They nurture blemishes and pick at wounds to produce weeping, suppurating flesh. Attractive creatures evoke disgust in a hag, which might "help" such creatures by disfiguring or transforming them.

This embrace of the disturbing and unpleasant extends to all aspects of a hag's life. A hag might fly in a magical giant's skull, landing it on a tree shaped to resemble an enormous headless body. Another might travel with a menagerie of monsters and slaves kept in cages, and disguised by illusions to lure unwary creatures close. Hags sharpen their teeth on millstones and spin cloth from the intestines of their victims,reacting with glee to the horror their actions invoke.

Dark Sorority. Hags maintain contact with each other and share knowledge. Through such contacts, it is likely that any given hag knows of every other hag in existence. Hags don't like each other, but they abide by an ageless code of conduct. Hags announce their presence before crossing into another hag's territory, bring gifts when entering another hag's dwelling, and break no oaths given to other hags-as long as the oath isn't given with the fingers crossed.

Some humanoids make the mistake of thinking thatthe hags' rules of conduct apply to all creatures. When confronted by such an individual, a hag might find it amusing to string the fool along for a while before teaching it a permanent lesson.

Dark Lairs. Hags dwell in dark and twisted woods, bleak moors, storm-lashed seacoasts, and gloomy swamps. In time, the landscape around a hag's lair reflects the creature's noxiousness, such that the land itself can attack and kill trespassers. Trees twisted by darkness attack passersby, while vines snake through the undergrowth to snare and drag off creatures one at a time. Foul stinking fogs turn the air to poison, and conceal pools of quicksand and sinkholes that consume unwary wanderers.

id-00001.desc: The hag can breathe air and water.
id-00001.name: Amphibious

id-00002.desc: The hag's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save DC 12). She can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:\n At will: dancing lights, minor illusion, vicious mockery
id-00002.name: Innate Spellcasting

id-00003.desc: The hag can mimic animal sounds and humanoid voices. A creature that hears the sounds can tell they are imitations with a successful DC 14 Wisdom (Insight) check.
id-00003.name: Mimicry

id-00001.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +6 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 13 (2d8 + 4) slashing damage.
id-00001.name: Claws (Hag Form Only)

id-00002.desc: The hag magically polymorphs into a Small or Medium female humanoid, or back into her true form. Her statistics are the same in each form. Any equipment she is wearing or carrying isn't transformed. She reverts to her true form if she dies.
id-00002.name: Change Shape

id-00003.desc: The hag magically enters the Ethereal Plane from the Material Plane, or vice versa. To do so, the hag must have a heartstone in her possession.
id-00003.name: Etherealness

id-00004.desc: While on the Ethereal Plane, the hag magically touches a sleeping humanoid on the Material Plane. A protection from evil and good spell cast on the target prevents this contact, as does a magic circle. As long as the contact persists, the target has dreadful visions. If these visions last for at least 1 hour, the target gains no benefit from its rest, and its hit point maximum is reduced by 5 (1d10). If this effect reduces the target's hit point maximum to 0, the target dies, and if the target was evil, its soul is trapped in the hag's soul bag. The reduction to the target's hit point maximum lasts until removed by the greater restoration spell or similar magic.
id-00004.name: Nightmare Haunting (1/Day)

id-00014.damageresistances: cold, fire; bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing from nonmagical attacks that aren't silvered

id-00001.desc:
Level: 1 (Ritual)
Casting Time: 1 action
Components: V, S
Duration: Concentration, up to 10 minutes
Range: Self
For the duration, you sense the presence of magic within 30 feet of you. If you sense magic in this way, you can use your action to see a faint aura around any visible creature or object in the area that bears magic, and you learn its school of magic, if any. The spell can penetrate most barriers, but it is blocked by 1 foot of stone, 1 inch of common metal, a thin sheet of lead, or 3 feet of wood or dirt.
id-00001.name: Detect Magic (At will)

id-00002.desc:
Level: 0
Casting Time: 1 action
Components: V
Duration: Instantaneous
Range: 60 feet
You unleash a string of insults laced with subtle enchantments at a creature you can see within range. If the target can hear you (though it need not understand you), it must succeed on a DC 12 Wisdom saving throw or take 1d4 psychic damage and have disadvantage on the next attack roll it makes before the end of its next turn. This spell's damage increases by 1d4 when you reach 5th level (2d4), 11th level (3d4), and 17th level (4d4).
id-00002.name: Vicious Mockery (At will)

id-00004.desc:
Level: 2
Casting Time: 1 action
Components: V, S
Duration: Concentration, up to 1 minute
Range: 60 feet
A black beam of enervating energy springs from your finger toward a creature within range. Make a ranged spell attack (+6 to hit) against the target. On a hit, the target deals only half damage with weapon attacks that use Strength until the spell ends. At the end of each of the target's turns, it can make a DC 14 Constitution saving throw against the spell. On a success, the spell ends.
id-00004.name: Ray of Enfeeblement (1/day)

id-00005.desc:
Level: 1
Casting Time: 1 action
Components: V, S, M (a pinch of fine sand, rose petals, or a cricket)
Duration: 1 minute
Range: 90 feet
This spell sends creatures into a magical slumber. Roll 5d8; the total is how many hit points of creatures this spell can affect. Creatures within 20 feet of a point you choose within range are affected in ascending order of their current hit points (ignoring unconscious creatures). Starting with the creature that has the lowest current hit points, each creature affected by this spell falls unconscious until the spell ends, the sleeper takes damage, or someone uses an action to shake or slap the sleeper awake. Subtract each creature's hit points from the total before moving on to the creature with the next lowest hit points. A creature's hit points must be equal to or less than the remaining total for that creature to be affected. Undead and creatures immune to being charmed aren't affected by this spell. At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, roll an additional 2d8 for each slot level above 1st.
id-00005.name: Sleep (1/day)

id-00014.name: Annis (weakened)

text.p: Sly and subversive, night hags want to see the virtuous turn to villainy: love turned into obsession, kindness turned to hate, devotion to disregard, and generosity to selfishness. Night hags take perverse joy in corrupting mortals.
Night hags were once creatures of the Feywild, but their foulness saw them exiled to Hades long ago, where they degenerated into fiends. The night hags have long since spread across the Lower Planes.

Soulmongers. While a humanoid sleeps, a night hag can straddle the person ethereally and intrude upon its dreams. Any creature with truesight can see the hag's spectral form straddling its prey. The ethereal hag fills her victim's head with doubts and fears, in the hope of tricking it into performing evil acts in the waking world. The hag continues her nightly visitations until the victim finally expires in its sleep. If the hag has driven her victim to commit evil deeds, she traps its corrupted soul in her soul bag (see the "Night Hag Items" sidebar) for transport to Hades.
Covens. A night hag that is part of a coven (see the "Hag Covens" sidebar) has a challenge rating of 7 (2,900 XP).

A night hag carries two very rare magic items that she must craft for herself. If either object is lost, the night hag will go to great lengths to retrieve it, as creating a new tool takes time and effort.
Heartstone. This lustrous black gem allows a night hag to become ethereal while it is in her possession. The touch of a heartstone also cures any disease. Crafting a heartstone takes 30 days.

Soul Bag. When an evil humanoid dies as a result of a night hag's Nightmare Haunting, the hag catches the soul in this black sack made of stitched flesh. A soul bag can hold only one evil soul at a time, and only the night hag who crafted the bag can catch a soul with it. Crafting a soul bag takes 7 days and a humanoid sacrifice (whose flesh is used to make the bag).
Hags represent all that is evil and cruel. Though they resemble withered crones, there is nothing mortal about these monstrous creatures, whose forms reflect only the wickedness in their hearts.
